statement.p:
The degree distribution of a graph is given by
p_k = \mbox{ the fraction of vertices with degree } k.
What is the degree distribution (p_1, p_2, \ldots) of this graph?

We are given a data set whose degree distribution looks like a straight line with negative slope when plotted using a log-log scale. In other words,
\ln (p(k)) = c - \alpha \ln (k),
where c >0 and \alpha > 0 are constants. Exponentiate both sides to show that
p(k) = C k^{-\alpha}.
What is the value of the constant C in terms of c?

p.ol:
\item Let p: \Z^+ \rightarrow [0,1] given by
p(k) = C k^{- \alpha}
be the PMF for a power law. (Here, we assume that p(0)=0 for convenience.) Suppose that we know the value for \alpha. Prove that
C = \frac{1}{\zeta(\alpha)}
where \zeta(x) is the Riemann zeta function
\displaystyle{\zeta(x) = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k^{-x}}.
What is the restriction on allowable values of \alpha?
For many real-world networks, the power law behavior doesn't hold for small k. In this case, we restrict our attention to vertices of degree at least k_{\min}. We then deal with the probability mass function for a truncated power law. Given \alpha and k \geq k_{\min} this PMF is given by
p(k) = \frac{ k^{-\alpha}}{\zeta(\alpha, k_{\min})}
where
\zeta(x, k_{\min}) = \sum_{k=k_{\min}}^{\infty} k^{-x}
is the generalized Riemann zeta function.
Dealing with the Riemann zeta function is unwieldy. In practice, we approximate this leading constant by the corresponding integral. Evaluate the following integral in order to find the approximate value for \zeta(\alpha, k_{\min}):
\sum_{k= k_{\min}}^{\infty} k^{-\alpha} \approx \int_{x= k_{\min}}^{\infty} x^{-\alpha} \, dx.
Find the corresponding approximate expression for the power law PMF p(x) using your constant from (b). Simplify so that \alpha only appears once in an exponent.

exercise.title: Approximating with a Continuous Power Law

idx.h: Approximating with a Continuous Power Law

statement.p:
In general, it is easier to pretend that we are dealing with a continuous distribution (rather than a discrete distribution). So we will talk about a probability density function (PDF) p: [k_{\min}, n] \rightarrow [0,1] given by
p(x) = C x^{-\alpha}
rather than a PMF. You can find the constant C = (\alpha-1)k_{\min}^{\alpha-1} as you did in the previous problem. But let's just keep calling it C for now.
Let X be a random variable governed by the continuous PDF p(x). Find
\E[X] = \int_{x=k_{\min}}^{n} x p(x) dx.
The mth moment of X is
\E[X^m] = \int_{x=k_{\min}}^{n} x^m p(x) dx.
Calculate it.
Look at your answers for parts (a) and (b) and think about what happens as n \rightarrow \infty. For what values of \alpha does \E[X] converge? When does the mth moment \E[X^m] converge?
Recall that most observed power laws have 2 \leq \alpha \leq 3. In this range, does the expected value converge? Which moments converge, and which moments diverge?
